Linear Fixed Effect Model

Source: vignettes/Linear-FE.Rmd
Linear-FE.Rmd

Estimation

In general R methods such as lm and glm, fitting fixed-effects models requires converting the provider factor into dummy variables. Each provider is represented by one dummy column in the design matrix 𝐃\mathbf{D}, set to 1 for observations belonging to that provider and 0 otherwise. Combined with the covariate matrix 𝐙\mathbf{Z}, the full design matrix is 𝐗=[𝐙,𝐃]\mathbf{X} = [\mathbf{Z}, \mathbf{D}], where 𝐙\mathbf{Z} is the covariate matrix and 𝐃\mathbf{D} is the mm-column dummy matrix indicating provider membership.

When the number of providers mm is large, creating and inverting this many dummy variables becomes computationally expensive in terms of both memory and processing time. To avoid the high dimensionality of dummy variables, pprof uses a profile likelihood approach. The ordinary least squares objective is

S(γ,β)=∑i=1m∑j=1ni(Yij−γi−𝐙ij⊤𝛃)2. S(\gamma, \beta) = \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \bigl(Y_{ij} - \gamma_i - \mathbf{Z}_{ij}^\top \boldsymbol\beta\bigr)^2.

Fixing 𝛃\boldsymbol\beta, set ∂S∂γi=0\frac{\partial S}{\partial \gamma_i} = 0 to obtain

γ̂FE,i=Y‾i−𝐙‾i⊤𝛃,i=1,…,m, \hat\gamma_{FE,i} = \bar{Y}_i - \bar{\mathbf{Z}}_i^\top \boldsymbol\beta, \quad i = 1, \ldots, m,

where

Y‾i=ni−1∑j=1niYij,𝐙‾i=ni−1∑j=1ni𝐙ij. \bar{Y}_i = n_i^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^{n_i} Y_{ij}, \quad \bar{\mathbf{Z}}_i = n_i^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \mathbf{Z}_{ij}.

Substituting back yields the profile objective for 𝛃\boldsymbol\beta, equivalent to centering each provider’s data:

Ỹij=𝐙̃ij⊤𝛃+ϵ̃ij, \tilde{Y}_{ij} = \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij}^\top \boldsymbol\beta + \tilde{\epsilon}_{ij},

with Ỹij=Yij−Y‾i,𝐙̃ij=𝐙ij−𝐙‾i,ϵ̃ij=ϵij−ϵ‾i\tilde{Y}_{ij} = Y_{ij} - \bar{Y}_i, \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij} = \mathbf{Z}_{ij} - \bar{\mathbf{Z}}_i, \tilde{\epsilon}_{ij} = \epsilon_{ij} - \bar{\epsilon}_i.

Estimation of Regression Coefficients

The closed-form estimator for 𝛃\boldsymbol\beta is

$$ \widehat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{FE} = \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij} \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij}^\top\Bigr)^{-1} \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij} \tilde{Y}_{ij}\Bigr) = \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \mathbf{Z}_i^\top \mathbf{Q}_i \mathbf{Z}_i\Bigr)^{-1} \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \mathbf{Z}_i^\top \mathbf{Q}_i \mathbf{Y}_i\Bigr), $$

where 𝐐i=𝐈ni−𝟏ni𝟏ni⊤/ni\mathbf{Q}_i = \mathbf{I}_{n_i} - \mathbf{1}_{n_i}\mathbf{1}_{n_i}^\top / n_i.

Variance and Inference

The residual variance is estimated by

σ̂ϵ2=1n−m−p∑i=1m∑j=1ni(Yij−γ̂FE,i−𝐙ij⊤𝛃̂FE)2. \hat\sigma_{\epsilon}^2 = \frac{1}{n - m - p} \sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \bigl(Y_{ij} - \hat\gamma_{FE,i} - \mathbf{Z}_{ij}^\top \widehat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{FE}\bigr)^2.

Under this model, 𝛃̂FE\widehat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{FE} and γ̂FE,i\hat\gamma_{FE,i} are unbiased, with

$$ \mathrm{Var}(\widehat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{FE}) = \sigma_{\epsilon}^2 \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \mathbf{Z}_i^\top \mathbf{Q}_i \mathbf{Z}_i\Bigr)^{-1}, \quad \mathrm{Var}(\hat\gamma_{FE,i}) = \frac{\sigma_{\epsilon}^2}{n_i}. $$
